{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3656223,"name":"Ethan Grieshop","username":"CakeDeer6","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cakedeer6/{size}/264680_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-17T04:01:07.771Z","cooked":"

I was reviewing some log files from earlier in the season today and started to notice a weird pattern. When disabled, our logged values would update every 20ms, like expected. (We used the feedback decorator for all of our logging during the second half of the season) However, when enabled, we received NetworkTables value updates every 60ms, which was unexpected because feedbacks should be posted every periodic cycle, and the default periodic cycle should be 20ms.

Early on in the season, we published our values using the Shuffleboard API within our execute method, but we changed over to using Feedback because it made our code more readable and less prone to mistakes with logging. Comparing our late season logs to log files from our week 3 competition, I noticed that the values updated at around 20ms, meaning our change from Shuffleboard to Feedback led to this change in performance.

Upon reviewing DriverStation logs, I found that each component would have loop times ranging from 0.1ms to 10ms, keeping us right around the 20ms benchmark at our week three competition (Note that the @magicbot.feedback timer was around 0.000001 seconds per periodic cycle). However, in our later competitions, we had similar cycle times in each component, but the main difference, @magicbot.feedback was consistently between 0.02 and 0.04 seconds per periodic cycle, meaning we were between doubling and tripling our allotted loop time.

In all fairness, we were sending nearly 200 unique items over NetworkTables using Feedback, so this issue wouldn’t be as noticeable for a team using it more sparingly. However, the fact that the Shuffleboard API was able to do this with a negligible performance hit means that Feedback is orders of magnitude slower than Shuffleboard, which confuses me because they should be relatively similar in performance.

All this to say: Is there a hidden functionality of the Feedback class causing this performance hit, a bug within Feedback, or are we misusing it altogether?

That’s really weird. There were no magicbot changes after kickoff.

The amount of time involved (200 ~ 400ms) sounds like you were calling a slow CAN API function in one of the feedback functions.

I don’t have access to our bot right now, so it’s hard to do any conclusive testing, but one thing I can say is that when we logged the pitch and roll readings from our gyro, the loop overruns became unbearable to the point that we had to do a complete of our code right before worlds. drivetrain.py also happened to have the longest periodic times by far of any component, which makes me wonder if the gyro’s CAN API call was the one that threw everything off.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2025-06-17T11:14:01.506Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":92,"readers_count":91,"score":18.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":503284,"topic_slug":"magicbot-feedback-feature-causes-loop-overruns","display_username":"Ethan Grieshop","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":11063,"username":"virtuald","name":"Dustin Spicuzza","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/virtuald/{size}/65268_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62698,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4611 Programmer + Driver"},"post_url":"/t/magicbot-feedback-feature-causes-loop-overruns/503284/3","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3656820,"name":"Ethan Grieshop","username":"CakeDeer6","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cakedeer6/{size}/264680_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-17T19:44:11.238Z","cooked":"

Ok, after reviewing some log files, it looks like the CAN API in general could be the culprit here. Since NetworkTables values are ordered by when they’re sent during a match in a log file, I was able to parse the file by comparing timestamps to find how long each feedback was taking. I tracked both the minimum and median response time, and it seemed that there was definitely a pattern.

As a base case, I looked at values already present in memory that didn’t require a CAN API call (such as the output of a PID controller or a component of an estimated pose). These gave a rough idea of how long each Shuffleboard API call takes, with a general minimum response time of around 0.02ms with a median of 0.03ms.

With anything that made a call to the CAN bus, there was a much more noticeable delay, with medians around 0.4-0.5ms and minimum response times around 0.2-0.3ms per API call, a sharp uptick from the base response time.

This makes a lot more sense now; once we started using Feedback for logging, we began send much more stuff over NetworkTables. For example, on our drivetrain in week 3, we would only send the positions of each motor/encoder, but by the end of the season, were sending position, velocity, current, voltage, etc.

It’s really annoying that the CAN APIs work this way.

Would it be possible to run Feedbacks asynchronously on the backend? Possibly via multithreading?

We’re not running freethreaded Python yet, so there can only be a single thread running in Python code at any point in time, thanks to the Global Interpreter Lock (GIL).
